quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It's very, very tempting to float up here as a leader and say, "Hey, you take that hill over there. You guys do this over here."
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Highlights the common leadership failure mode of directing from afar instead of engaging with real work.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When in fact, where you really learn where the challenges are, or the problems or the successes is by just being there with the people in the trenches on one of the things, whichever one seems hardest or most complicated.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to go deep on the hardest problem to uncover true constraints and opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And so I try to do that as often as I can, and I found that I always learn a lot by going through that detailed exercise.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Reinforces a repeatable practice—hands-on deep dives—as a learning mechanism for leaders.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Previously, he was chief product officer at Coinbase where he oversaw 10 x growth of the product and engineering organizations and helped scale Coinbase during one of the craziest times in the crypto markets.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete scaling data point (10x org growth) that anchors the credibility of the upcoming lessons.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The best way to see what Miro's all about and how we can help your team collaborate better is not to listen to me talk about it, but to go check it out for yourself, go to miro.com/lenny.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Emphasizes a hands-on evaluation approach over relying on marketing explanations—useful for choosing tools quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With the help of the Miro team, I created a super cool Miro board with two of my own favorite templates, my one-pager template and my managing up template that you can plug and play and start using immediately with your team.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights a practical “plug and play” template-based workflow for faster team alignment and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Miro is a killer tool for brainstorming with your team, laying out your strategy, sharing user research findings, capturing ideas, giving feedback on wireframes, and generally just collaborating with your colleagues.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Provides a concrete checklist of high-leverage collaboration use cases teams can adopt immediately.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Get deep insights into what your users are doing at every stage of the funnel at a fair price that scales as you grow.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Encourages funnel-wide measurement with tooling that can scale economically—relevant for growing product teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Powered by first-party behavioral data instead of third party cookies, Mixpanel is built to be more powerful and easier to use than Google Analytics.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Points to a shift toward first-party behavioral analytics as a more robust approach than cookie-dependent tracking.

quotes.topic_title: Coinbase hypergrowth during the 2017 crypto boom
quotes.text: Coinbase, which at the time had an exchange just like on-ramp and off-ramp from fiat to crypto and back experienced over the course of 2017 40 x growth in usage.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A concrete hypergrowth data point that frames the scale of operational and product challenges teams must be ready to absorb.

quotes.topic_title: Coinbase hypergrowth during the 2017 crypto boom
quotes.text: No, I mean it was both a dream and a nightmare and I was incredibly lucky to be working on it with a team of people that I could really trust and could stand shoulder-to-shoulder within the trenches.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Highlights the counterintuitive reality that hypergrowth can be as destabilizing as it is exciting—and that trust in teammates is a key scaling lever.

quotes.topic_title: Coinbase hypergrowth during the 2017 crypto boom
quotes.text: And it was a lot of learning about how you can rapidly scale systems over time and people like to trade crypto on Saturday mornings, so a lot of Saturday mornings just some new thing would break on the edges of the system and we need to get in there and work on it.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A vivid operational lesson: real-world usage patterns (weekends) will stress edge cases, so scaling requires incident readiness and continuous fixes.

quotes.topic_title: Coinbase hypergrowth during the 2017 crypto boom
quotes.text: And so it was just a lot of really incredible lessons about who you choose to work with and focus and making sure you have the right people in the room at the right time.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on prioritizing team composition and decision-making structure during high-uncertainty, high-incident periods.

quotes.topic_title: Staying focused amid volatility and security constraints
quotes.text: Well, the first thing is you don't talk about people getting rich. It's a very technical, you talk about like its customers, it's their money, and number one, it had to be secure.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Reframes hype-driven environments into a customer-trust and security-first problem to keep teams grounded and focused.

quotes.topic_title: Staying focused amid volatility and security constraints
quotes.text: he was able to always put these decisions that we were making extremely quickly in context and say, "Look, these are the kinds of decisions we can make and still have it be secure no matter how fast we need to move."
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A practical decision-making framework: move fast, but only within clearly defined security-safe boundaries.

quotes.topic_title: Staying focused amid volatility and security constraints
quotes.text: And then the second thing is focusing on both the kind of immediate nature of the issue. Hey, site is down or whatever, and resolving that, but also trying to set those in a context of where we need to go over the next six months.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A dual-track operating model: balance urgent incident response with a rolling medium-term plan.

quotes.topic_title: Staying focused amid volatility and security constraints
quotes.text: you have to be able to have those debates because lots is going on, but then you have to be able to come out of those conversations with a clear kind of company point of view that you're all shooting toward.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Shows how to handle high-uncertainty domains: encourage debate, then converge on a single directional “company POV.”

quotes.topic_title: Staying focused amid volatility and security constraints
quotes.text: And while there may still be differing points of views and debates that happen on the margins, you go full speed toward this answer until you decide to go full speed toward a different answer.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A commitment mechanism for volatile markets: align on a decision, execute decisively, and only switch when you explicitly re-commit.

quotes.topic_title: Handling uncertainty and learning through intense periods
quotes.text: I've always loved the rate of learning.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Reframes intense periods as valuable primarily because they maximize learning velocity.

quotes.topic_title: Handling uncertainty and learning through intense periods
quotes.text: And so it is those experiences I feel that have most sort of accelerated my own personal growth and personal learnings because it's in the crucible of things being hard.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Offers a mental model (“crucible”) for why high-stress moments can produce outsized growth.

quotes.topic_title: Handling uncertainty and learning through intense periods
quotes.text: And so I think when people are going through those times, it's nice to take a step back and talk with friends or whatever about what's really going on and setting it in the context of, hey, three, four or five years now from now when we look back on this, you realize, wow.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Actionable advice to use reflection and social processing to reframe stress with a longer time horizon.

quotes.topic_title: Handling uncertainty and learning through intense periods
quotes.text: A, we did something amazing with that time. And B, we learned a lot and we were able to take that with us into whatever we were doing next after that.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Provides a simple two-part retrospective rubric (impact + learning transfer) for finding the “silver lining.”

quotes.topic_title: Maintaining velocity at scale: teams, platforms, deep dives
quotes.text: I think there's kind of a universal truth that you want small teams with clear missions.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A simple operating principle for maintaining speed by reducing coordination overhead and sharpening ownership.

quotes.topic_title: Maintaining velocity at scale: teams, platforms, deep dives
quotes.text: If there's 300 people trying to work on one thing, the just sheer communication challenges, Dunbar's number, all of those things come into play and it's really, really hard to act quickly.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A concrete warning about how scale can directly slow execution through communication limits.

quotes.topic_title: Maintaining velocity at scale: teams, platforms, deep dives
quotes.text: The more you can bake into a clear platform, it reduces the decision-making complexity for everyone who's working on the domain part of the problem.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A platform-as-leverage model: centralize complexity so product/domain teams can move faster with fewer decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Maintaining velocity at scale: teams, platforms, deep dives
quotes.text: Platforms are not, you can't just write a platform and hope it's going to work for the products. It's very much an iterative thing, but the more one can invest in that and have the right kinds of people who are capable of doing that sort of both systems thinking and product thinking simultaneously, I think is really important.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Practical guidance on building platforms as iterative products and staffing them with hybrid systems+product thinkers.

quotes.topic_title: Maintaining velocity at scale: teams, platforms, deep dives
quotes.text: When in fact where you really learn where the challenges are or the problems or the successes is by just being there with the people in the trenches on one of the things, whichever one seems hardest or most complicated.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A leadership tactic for uncovering real bottlenecks: go deep on the hardest work rather than staying abstract.

quotes.topic_title: Rippling’s small-team model for launching new products
quotes.text: And those four people over the course of maybe nine months or so, built a time and attendance product.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A concrete example of how a tiny team can ship a full product in a defined timeframe.

quotes.topic_title: Rippling’s small-team model for launching new products
quotes.text: They were monomaniacally focused on this one thing and then identifying the places where yes, you, there's connectivity to the rest of the suite, and that allowed them to move extremely quickly.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A practical operating model: isolate a team’s mission while deliberately managing only the necessary integration points.

quotes.topic_title: Rippling’s small-team model for launching new products
quotes.text: But the thing is at Rippling, like we've now replicated that a dozen times. That's our model for starting new things.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Highlights a repeatable methodology for launching new product bets, not a one-off success dependent on a CEO.

quotes.topic_title: Rippling’s small-team model for launching new products
quotes.text: All of those things can happen just at a much greater tempo than if you're trying to go three layers down into the org and do things.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A counterpoint to heavy hierarchy: direct visibility and fewer layers increases speed of feedback and decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Rippling’s small-team model for launching new products
quotes.text: that management structure does not interfere with the ability of anyone anywhere in the organization to look at what's actually happening.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Actionable principle for org design: keep management from becoming a barrier to transparency and inspection.

quotes.topic_title: The “founder engineer + designer” incubation process
quotes.text: So we start there, we find a single engineer who is extremely entrepreneurial, understands what it means to operate at tempo, understands what it means to make decisions with low information, understands how to work very, very quickly with a design partner.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Defines the key selection criteria for the “founder engineer” who can drive a new product from zero-to-one under uncertainty.

quotes.topic_title: The “founder engineer + designer” incubation process
quotes.text: So we have a design partner and we say, "Look, come into Rippling, spend a few months getting to know the platform first of all. So go work on this other team, understand what's easy for them, what's hard for them, how the platform works, how other products have been built on top of this. Go talk with other people who founded products here and understand what their experience is so that you can learn from and iterate on it, get an opinion about your product, and then start building it."
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A concrete onboarding playbook for designers to internalize platform constraints and reuse patterns before starting a new product.

quotes.topic_title: The “founder engineer + designer” incubation process
quotes.text: And during this intervening time, they're also recruiting a team of usually 2, 3, 4 other engineers who kind of have that same zero-to-one mentality and they start building.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Shows how they staff early: a tiny team optimized for zero-to-one execution rather than scaling.

quotes.topic_title: The “founder engineer + designer” incubation process
quotes.text: And usually over the course of six to nine months, we can get a product from a blank sheet of paper to something that is launched or at least that we're using internally when we dogfood our stuff really heavily.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Provides a concrete timeline benchmark and emphasizes heavy internal dogfooding as part of the launch path.

quotes.topic_title: The “founder engineer + designer” incubation process
quotes.text: Sometimes you have to bump it up. It's like, okay, this thing's about to go to production, there's all these other things to do, the team needs now needs to go from 4 to 15 or something like that.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Captures the scaling heuristic: keep teams small until production demands force a step-change in headcount.

quotes.topic_title: Why Rippling avoids MVPs and designs complex-first
quotes.text: And the reason I believe that is that when you design a minimum viable product, you're optimizing for speed. And in that set of optimizations, you are minimizing the deeper product thinking about what can fully differentiate our product based on not only existing kind of capabilities within our products and platform, but based on what it ought to do in the future.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A contrarian critique of MVPs: speed optimization can crowd out differentiation and long-term product thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Why Rippling avoids MVPs and designs complex-first
quotes.text: And it's extremely difficult to unwind those decisions once you've built them into the product.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A warning that early architectural assumptions compound and become costly to reverse later.

quotes.topic_title: Why Rippling avoids MVPs and designs complex-first
quotes.text: You still build the product in a way that's not going to prevent you from getting there in the future.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A practical methodology: design for the hardest future case even if you don’t support it in v1.

quotes.topic_title: Why Rippling avoids MVPs and designs complex-first
quotes.text: And instead, what we have is 80% of the system is baked into our global payroll platform, and then the 20% is country-specific.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A concrete modularization model (80/20 platform vs. local variance) that enables scaling to new countries faster.

quotes.topic_title: Why Rippling avoids MVPs and designs complex-first
quotes.text: 100%, many times.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A clear directive reinforcing the complex-first design principle as an explicit team instruction.

quotes.topic_title: Compound startup and single system-of-record differentiation
quotes.text: The right answer is to have a single system of record, one place, one database where all of that information is resident so that each of these downstream systems can always have the right data at the right time.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A clear platform strategy: unify data first so every product built on top stays consistent without constant syncing and integrations.

quotes.topic_title: Compound startup and single system-of-record differentiation
quotes.text: And then you can build on top of that things like workflow and reporting and analytics and permissioning and all these kinds of underlying capabilities.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Highlights the compounding leverage of foundational primitives (workflows/permissions/analytics) once a unified system of record exists.

quotes.topic_title: Compound startup and single system-of-record differentiation
quotes.text: The activation energy for that is extremely high.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A memorable warning that the upfront investment to build a unified platform is steep, even if it pays off later via compounding advantages.

quotes.topic_title: Compound startup and single system-of-record differentiation
quotes.text: Most products you find some system of truth, export everybody's name and email address and a spreadsheet, have another email address or another name, maybe an employee ID of who that person reports to and upload that to another system, which by the way is immediately out of date because organizational structures change all the time.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A concrete example of how point-solution integrations decay in real life, creating operational drag and stale data.

quotes.topic_title: Compound startup and single system-of-record differentiation
quotes.text: So our ability to differentiate boils down to that one fundamental decision, which just allows us to do things that are literally impossible for any other company to do.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A differentiation thesis: one architectural decision (single system of record) can create durable, hard-to-copy product capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Culture of fast decision-making and leadership principles
quotes.text: It's like let's not schedule a meeting for next week or tomorrow or later today. We're in the middle of a meeting, we need to make a decision. Let's either make the decision or if we can't, let's Slack call in the person that we need in order to make that decision. And we'll be done with the decision today.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A concrete operating method for collapsing decision latency by resolving decisions in-meeting and pulling in missing stakeholders immediately.

quotes.topic_title: Culture of fast decision-making and leadership principles
quotes.text: And no company I've been at any scale, 5 people, 5,000 people, has ever operated at the tempo this one does.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A memorable benchmark that highlights how unusually high decision tempo can be a differentiator independent of company size.

quotes.topic_title: Culture of fast decision-making and leadership principles
quotes.text: In product, you don't own little feature, you own your product and you're expected to be the world's foremost expert in it.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A role-definition framework that ties fast decisions to deep domain ownership and expertise rather than committee-driven alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Culture of fast decision-making and leadership principles
quotes.text: It's like, no, no, that date passed. You don't get to retroactively make everybody react to the fact that you didn't operate quickly enough, right?
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A counterintuitive enforcement mechanism: deadlines are real, and missing them means the organization moves on instead of accommodating delays.

quotes.topic_title: Culture of fast decision-making and leadership principles
quotes.text: The way we came up with them was to us a couple years ago, to introspect and to what actually made people successful at the company? Like who's successful, why are they successful? Why do they enjoy being here? Or alternatively the opposite, like why people not worked out, why do some people not enjoy it here? And those are the things that are differentiating and those are the things that we wrote down.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A practical methodology for codifying leadership principles by reverse-engineering success and failure patterns inside the company.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Thousands of people apply to join this collective. And I personally review and accept just about 10% of them.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete quality-control benchmark (10% acceptance rate) that signals a highly curated talent pool.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can be anonymous and you can even hide yourself from specific companies.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical mechanism for candidates to explore opportunities with reduced risk and more control.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: you'll only hear from companies that you want to hear from.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Emphasizes an opt-in communication model that reduces noise and increases signal for job seekers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Join almost a 100 other companies who are actively hiring through this collective.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Offers a specific adoption data point that functions as social proof for hiring managers considering the channel.

quotes.topic_title: How to move faster: clarity, “go and see,” deep expertise
quotes.text: I think it starts with whoever is in the role of making the top-level product decisions of them being one extremely clear about what those priorities are and more importantly, extremely clear about what all the priorities aren't.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A practical prioritization rule: speed comes from explicitly defining both priorities and non-priorities to avoid distraction.

quotes.topic_title: How to move faster: clarity, “go and see,” deep expertise
quotes.text: So to look at the thing and then walk all the way to ground and talk with the engineer who's writing the code on the thing.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A concrete “go and see” method for leaders to reach ground truth by engaging directly with builders closest to the work.

quotes.topic_title: How to move faster: clarity, “go and see,” deep expertise
quotes.text: And you don't think about those things until you've gone all the way to ground and looked at how these things are actually worked, how they're communicated, and how they're thought through.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Explains why deep, firsthand investigation surfaces critical requirements that abstract discussions miss.

quotes.topic_title: How to move faster: clarity, “go and see,” deep expertise
quotes.text: That's right. You go do it. You go learn and then we can make the case for hiring the tax expert, which we do have by the way now.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Counterintuitive sequencing: product leaders should learn the domain deeply themselves before delegating to specialists.

quotes.topic_title: How to move faster: clarity, “go and see,” deep expertise
quotes.text: I think it's equally if a job is 80 hours a week, it's 40 of your hours.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A specific time-allocation heuristic that emphasizes spending roughly half your time building deep domain understanding.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders are right a lot: decision quality as a core skill
quotes.text: Because product leaders have to be right most of the time because their decisions reflect across the entire org and their decisions fundamentally spend time and they spend energy.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Frames product leadership as an org-wide resource allocation function where decision quality directly determines how time and energy get spent.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders are right a lot: decision quality as a core skill
quotes.text: And if they make good ones, the company does really well. And if they make bad ones, the company doesn't.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A blunt causal model that ties company performance to the quality of product leadership decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders are right a lot: decision quality as a core skill
quotes.text: And one of the things I really value in product leaders are people who can go into an ambiguous information with ambiguous situation, with incomplete information and a complex decision space and can look at that and listen to everybody and read whatever they need to read and say, this is where we need to go.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Describes a practical decision-making methodology under uncertainty: synthesize inputs, do the reading, then commit to a direction.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders are right a lot: decision quality as a core skill
quotes.text: And even if everyone else is like, ah, I don't know, that feels wrong for this reason, this reason if they have the confidence to make that call, and then a year later when you look back on it, for them to have been right, that's extremely valuable.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Highlights the value of making confident calls that withstand hindsight, even amid team disagreement.

quotes.topic_title: Leaders are right a lot: decision quality as a core skill
quotes.text: And it's the one value we have. It's like you can't really learn it. Either you're really, really good at making those kinds of decisions or you're not, right? It's a very peculiar skill that we really value.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A provocative claim that high-quality decision-making under ambiguity is largely innate and difficult to train, affecting how you hire and evaluate leaders.

quotes.topic_title: Global expansion: choosing countries and starting earlier
quotes.text: But if we just look at our US-based companies, we know that there is immediate demand for those people to pay people in countries X, Y, and Z. And we just listed those out in raw numerical order.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A concrete, data-driven starting point for country prioritization: rank expansion targets by observed customer demand.

quotes.topic_title: Global expansion: choosing countries and starting earlier
quotes.text: And then we kind of looked at, okay, how hard is it to build in these countries and how valuable is it to build in these countries? What is the strategic value of building in the UK or Canada or Germany or India or wherever?
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A practical prioritization rubric: combine demand with build difficulty and strategic value to choose markets.

quotes.topic_title: Global expansion: choosing countries and starting earlier
quotes.text: And we just stack-ranked them and then we revisited that decision.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: An iterative operating model for expansion planning: commit to a ranked list, then regularly re-evaluate as you learn.

quotes.topic_title: Global expansion: choosing countries and starting earlier
quotes.text: I think the right answer to that question is always before you think you do before you think you need to because there are, it's harder than everyone if they've never done it before, it's harder than you think it is.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: Counterintuitive timing advice: start international expansion earlier because complexity is consistently underestimated.

quotes.topic_title: Global expansion: choosing countries and starting earlier
quotes.text: It stopped being the province of 100-person companies plus and started filtering down into very, very small companies.
quotes.speaker: Jeremy Henrickson
quotes.context: A specific observation about post-COVID globalization: multi-country operations are now common even for small companies, accelerating expansion timelines.
